Graphical abstract 1-phenylpyrrole moieties bind on Co surface through π bond. Concurrently, LiPSs interact with both Co surface and 1-phenylpyrrole through N∙∙∙Li bond, which simultaneously promotes the conversion kinetics of LiPSs. The electrochemical performance of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries is strongly hampered by the shuttle effect and slow redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). Surface modified interlayer of a separator of Li-S batteries is demonstrated to be an effective strategy to overcome this problem. Herein, cobalt nanoparticles confined in nitrogen co-doped porous carbon framework (Co-CN) were developed from pyrolysis of ZIF-67 and used as interlayer of PP separator for Li-S batteries, and were functionalized by four pyrrole derivatives, 1-phenylpyrrole, 1-methyl pyrrole, 1-(p-toluenesulfonyl) pyrrole, and 1-pyrrole, respectively, which were screened in terms of the electron-withdrawing/donating ability of the substituent groups on the pyrrolic nitrogen. The impact of the molecular structure of pyrrole derivatives on the interaction with LiPSs and the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries were explored by nuclear magnetic resonance and theoretical calculation. It is uncovered that 1-phenylpyrrole shows the highest enhancement of redox kinetics of LiPSs, attributing to the optimal interaction with Co nanoparticles and LiPSs. Therefore, 1-phenylpyrrole modified Co-CN interlayer enables the best electrochemical performance for the Li-S batteries, delivering a specific capacity of 562 mAh g−1 at 5 C and a capacity of 538, 526, and 449 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1, 2, and 3 C, respectively. At a high sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2, it achieves a capacity of 440 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C. This work reveals the interaction mechanism among LiPSs, Co nanoparticles and the molecular modifiers in improving the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Keywords Pyrrole derivatives Surface modification Interlayer Catalysis Redox kinetics 1 Introduction Lithium-Sulfur (Li-S) batteries have received widespread attention due to their high specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1) and energy density (2600 Wh kg−1) [1,2]. However, the shuttle effect and slow redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) limit capacity and long-term cycling stability of Li-S batteries [3–6]. To address these issues, researchers have developed porous carbon [7,8], polar metal compounds [9–12], and organic polymers [13–15] as sulfur cathode materials, which suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs not only through physical confinement but also promoted redox kinetics of LiPSs as electrocatalysts [16]. Designing a functional interlayer [17–19] for PP separator [20,21] is recognized as another effective and efficient approach and many polar materials [22], such as Fe3C [23], Co2B@CNT [24], MnO x -CeO2 [25], Co9S8 [26], and rGO@CoSe2 [27] and Co nanoparticles supported on porous carbon materials [28] have been developed as functional interlayer and advanced catalysts, which increases the redox reaction rate of LiPSs and enable excellent electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Recent studies have shown that organic functional materials behave as an excellent interlayer modifier for separators, where the charged functional groups can effectively interact with the LiPSs and limit the shuttle effect [29]. Pyrrole and polypyrroles (PPy) have also been demonstrated as one kind of these organic functional modifiers for interlayers operating in Li-S batteries, which are formed by electrochemical oxidation polymerization during charging and discharging process [30] or in-situ growth [31], where the PPy can inhibit the shuttle effect of LiPSs intermediates by forming N-Li-S. PPy can also be combined with transition metal nanoparticles and oxide compounds [32–34] through in-situ pyrrole polymerization, while maintaining its good flexibility and electrical conductivity and significantly enhancing the cycling and rate performance of the Li-S batteries. Currently, the attention has been focused on the architecture of PPy [35] as the component of cathode or functionalization of the interlayer for improvement of electrode conductivity and the molecular interaction between PPy and LiPSs, while the impact of molecular structure of pyrrole monomer on interaction between pyrrole and LiPSs and on electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries has been largely neglected. Herein, Co-CN nanocomposites as interlayer of Li-S batteries were prepared, modified with pyrrole derivatives, and systematically explored to understand the impact of methyl, phenyl, and p-toluene sulfonyl functional groups of the pyrrolic nitrogen atoms on the redox kinetics of LiPSs. It is observed that 1-phenylpyrrole enables the best performance for Li-S batteries, which was ascribed to the optimized sulfophilic interaction with both LiPSs and Co surface. Therefore, 1-phenylpyrrole modified Co-CN interlayer delivers the highest electrochemical performance among these pyrrole derivatives. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1-(p-toluenesulfonyl) pyrrole (Tsyrl, 99%), 1-pyrrole (Pyrl, AR), 1-methyl pyrrole (Mypyrl, 99%), 1-phenylpyrrole (Phpyrl, >98%), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, AR, >99%), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2∙6H2O), methanol (99%), sulfur (99.99%), ethanol (AR, ≥99.99%), 2-methylimidazole (98%) and chloroform-d (CDCl3, 99.8 atom%, contains 0.03% (v/v) TMS) were obtained from Energy Chemical Co. Carbon nanotube (CNT) was supplied by Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co. All chemicals were consumed without further purification. A Barnstead Nano pure water system (18.3 MΩ cm) supplies the deionized water. 2.2 Synthesis of ZIF-67 and Co-CN nanoparticles Typically, 80 mmol 2-methylimidazole and 20 mmol Co(NO3)2∙6H2O were dissolved in 500 mL methanol solution, respectively, mixed quickly and stirred at room temperature for 1 h, and the mixed solution sit for 24 h. Afterwards, precipitates were gathered by centrifugation at 3000 r min−1 for 5 min, washed with absolute ethanol three times, and air-dried in an oven at 60 °C overnight to obtain ZIF-67 powder. Later, ZIF-67 powder was annealed in a porcelain boat at 700 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 under an Ar/H2 (10%) atmosphere for 3 h. The obtained cobalt nanoparticles mixed with nitrogen co-doped carbon framework are denoted as Co-CN. 2.3 Fabrication of functional interlayers A vacuum infiltration process was applied to fabricate the functional interlayers. Generally, Co-CN (60 mg), PVDF (30 mg), and pyrrole derivatives (1 g) were poured into an NMP/ethanol solution (1:5 by volume) and sonicated to produce a homogeneous solution, which was then uniformly loaded onto a commercial polypropylene separator (PP, Celgard-2400) by vacuum filtration. The functionalized separator was dried in an oven at 60 °C for 24 h. The Co-CN interlayers modified with Phpyrl, Pyrl, Mypyrl, and Tsyrl were also prepared by a similar pathway and the resulted interlayer was named Phpyrl/Co-CN, Pyrl/Co-CN, Tsyrl/Co-CN, Mypyrl/Co-CN interlayer, respectively. The loading of the functionalized Co-CN interlayer is approximately 0.25 mg cm−2. As a control, Co-CN modified separator was prepared by the same procedure without adding any organic molecules. 2.4 Fabrication of sulfur cathode and electrochemical measurement In general, sulfur powder was mixed with CNT at a mass ratio of 4:6 by grinding for 30 min and annealed in a tube furnace under Ar atmosphere at 155 °C for 12 h to melt sulfur into CNT (S/CNT), which was followed by annealing at 200 °C for 2 h to remove excess sulfur that was not incorporated into the CNT. The sulfur loaded CNT are denoted as S/CNT. To prepare a cathode, a slurry was prepared in advance by mixing S/CNT, Super-P, and PVDF in a weight ratio of 70:15:15 in NMP solvent and loaded on an aluminum foil with a carbon coating, and finally dried in an oven at 60 °C for 24 h. The sulfur loading of the cathode is about 1.2–1.5 mg cm−2 and the E/S ratio (the electrolyte to sulfur) is 20 mL g−1. The diameter of the cathode and anode is 13 and 15.6 mm, respectively. The thickness of the Li chips is 0.45 mm. The CR2016 coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box (Vigor-LG2400/750TS, China) where the oxygen and water level are less than 1 ppm. Briefly, a lithium foil, the sulfur electrode prepared above, and the modified PP separator were applied as an anode, cathode, and separator, respectively. The hybrid solvent of DOL/DME (1, 3-dioxolane = DOL; dimethyl ether = DME, volume ratio of 1:1) containing 1.0 M LiTFSI (TFSI = bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)) and 0.2 M LiNO3 was applied as the electrolyte. The LAND test instruments (CT2001A, LAND Electronic Co., Ltd., China) were applied to test the charge/discharge performances of the Li-S coin cells at a constant temperature of 28 °C. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out on an electrochemical workstation (CHI750E, Chenhua) at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 in a voltage window of 1.8 to 2.7 V. Besides, in order to investigate the Li ion diffusion, the CV measurements were carried out with a scan rate of 0.2 to 0.5 mV s−1 in a voltage window of 1.8 to 2.7 V. The frequency range in EIS measurement is from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz and an amplitude of 0.1 mV is applied. The charge/discharge curves are obtained from cycling the battery in the LAND test instruments and the test currents are calculated from the active substance of the cathode. All the specific mass capacities of Li-S batteries were obtained by normalizing the capacity to the mass of sulfur. 2.5 Test of Li2S6 adsorption To obtain Li2S6 solution, sulfur and lithium sulfide in a molar ratio of 5:1 were dissolved into a DME/DOL solution (1:1 by volume) and stirred for 24 h at 60 °C in an Ar-filled glovebox. The same quality of Phpyrl/Co-CN and Co-CN powders were added into 10 mL 10 mM Li2S6 solution and rested for 12 h. The supernatant was then collected for the test of UV–vis spectroscopy. 2.6 Characterization The crystal structure of samples was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) under Cu K α radiation source (Bruker D8 Advanced, German). The surface chemical states of Co-CN and Phpyrl/Co-CN were detected through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI X-tool, Japan) using Al K α as an X-ray source. The microscopic morphology of samples was explored through field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU8000, Japan). The UV-vis spectra were collected by UV-2600. Liquid NMR spectroscopic measurements were carried out in CDCl3 with a Bruker 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. 2.7 Assembly and test of symmetrical cell Symmetric cells were prepared by using the active Phpyrl/Co-CN (or Co-CN) as both working and counter electrode, respectively. To prepare an active electrode, a slurry was prepared in advance by mixing Phpyrl/Co-CN (or Co-CN), super P, and PVDF in a mass ratio of 70:15:15, which were then coated on an Al foil and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 24 h. The symmetrical cell was assembled using the standard electrolyte mentioned above but additionally containing 0.5 M Li2S6. The counterpart electrolyte without Li2S6 was applied as a blank electrolyte. The separator in symmetrical cell was a PP membrane. The active materials loaded on all the cathodes of coin cells were nearly 1.21 mg cm−2 and the volume of the applied electrolyte is 40 µL. CV scans for symmetric cells were performed at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 in a voltage range from −0.8 and 0.8 V. 2.8 Theoretical calculation Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was performed using the CASTEP package in Materials Studio and the details of the calculation can be in our previous reports [36,37]. In brief, a face center cubic Co (111) tablet was built with 3 layers of 8 × 8 surface unit cells. The adsorption configuration and adsorption energy (ΔE) of pyrrole derivatives on Co (111) are calculated. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) displays clearly dodecahedron shape of ZIF-67 at the scale of 800 nm. After annealing at 700 °C under Ar/H2 atmosphere, Co-CN nanocomposites were obtained [38], where Co nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes were observed as bright dots and wires on the carbon matrix, as shown in Fig. 1(b). The formation of Co nanoparticles was further verified by XRD measurement, as shown in Fig. S1 [39]. The diffraction peak located at 26° is indexed into the (002) reflection of graphite [40]. The pore size distribution and specific surface area of Co-CN composite were characterized by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method, as shown in Fig. S2. The pore size distribution of Co-CN composite is between 1 to 7 nm and the curve is a typical IV curve, indicating its mesoporous structure. The specific surface area of Co-CN is 279.5 m2 g−1. TEM and HRTEM images show that the Co nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the carbon substrate, with an average size of approximately 4.1 ± 1.5 nm (Figs. S3 and S4). After coupling 1-phenylpyrrole, the surface of Co-CN becomes darker in SEM image (Fig. 1c). To further confirm the coupling Co-CN with 1-phenylpyrrole, the 1H NMR was performed and shown in Fig. S5. Clearly, the peak of the C-H in 1-phenylpyrrole next to the pyrrolic N (α-H) broadens for Phpyrl/Co-CN sample, indicating that the successful modification of 1-phenylpyrrole on Co nanoparticles in Co-CN composite. Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer was prepared by vacuum filtration, as demonstrated in Fig. 1(d). Fig. 1(e) shows the morphology of the Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer, which clearly shows that the Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer is uniformly distributed on the surface of PP separator. The thickness of the Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer on the PP separator is about 11 μm (Fig. S6a). The surface wetting ability of Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer was examined by contact angle measurement, as shown in Fig. 1(f). Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer displays smaller contact angle (8°) than Co-CN/PP (14°, Fig. S6b) and PP separator (31°), indicating enhanced wettability of Co-CN by functionalization of Phpyrl, which is beneficial to the penetration of electrolyte [41–43]. Fig. 1(g) shows that the Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer is robust against the mechanical stress and no visible cracking was observed after recovery of bending, showing excellent application potential in wearable devices [28]. To explore the synergistic effect of pyrrole derivatives and Co nanoparticles and the impact of the molecular structure on the interaction of pyrrole derivatives with LiPSs, pyrrole derivatives-modified Co-CN interlayer was coated on PP separator by vacuum filtration and the electrochemical performance was performed, as shown in Fig. 2 . The exact amount of sulfur in CNT/S composites was 58.69 wt% from TGA curve (Fig. S7). The CV curves of Li-S batteries are shown in Fig. 2(a), where the battery with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer displays two cathodic peaks at 2.28 V (A) and 2.05 V (B), which correspond to the transition of S8 to long-chain LiPSs (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n < 8) then to short-chain (Li2S n ,1 ≤ n < 4) LiPSs and finally to Li2S2/Li2S [44], respectively, while the two anodic peaks at 2.32 V (C) and 2.36 V (D) correspond to sequential oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to LiPSs and S8 [45–47]. The surface modification of Co-CN by Phpyrl negatively shifted the anodic peak potential apparently and increased the current density. The voltage polarizations derived from Fig. 2(a) are shown in Fig. 2(b), which are 264, 276, 281, and 284 mV for Phpyrl, Pyrl, Tsyrl, and Mypyrl modified Co-CN interlayers and 288 and 300 mV for Co-CN interlayer and pristine PP separator, respectively. Fig. 2(c) displays the rate performance of Li-S batteries and the capacity of Li-S batteries at a current density of 5 C (1 C = 1675 mA g−1) is 562, 348, 239, and 189 mAh g−1 for the Li-S batteries using Phpyrl, Pyrl, Tsyrl, and Mypyrl modified Co-CN interlayers, and 164 and 116 mAh g−1 for Co-CN and pristine PP, respectively. Fig. S8 shows the charge–discharge profiles for the rate performance of Li-S batteries, and Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer displays obvious charge–discharge platforms even at a current density of 5 C. The batteries with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer also exhibit minimal voltage polarization at different current densities as shown in Fig. 2(d) [48]. All these results suggest that the redox kinetics of LiPSs are improved by Co-CN and pyrrole derivatives-modified Co-CN functional interlayer, respectively, and Phpyrl enables the highest redox kinetics of LiPSs in the battery [36]. The 1H NMR spectra of the four pyrrole derivatives were performed to explore the influence of substituent groups on the pyrrolic N and the interaction with LiPSs. As shown in Fig. S9, it is observed that the chemical shift (δ) of C-H next to pyrrolic N (α-H) is strongly dependent on the substituent group. Phenyl group is a weak electron-withdrawing group, which results in a reduction in the electron density of H atom on pyrrole ring and a reduced shielding effect, thereby shifting the chemical shift of α-H to the low field. Tsyrl leads to a shift of α-H to a lower field due to a stronger electron-withdrawing ability than the phenyl. In contrast, methyl group, being an electron-donating group, causes a shift of α-H to higher field than pyrrole. The 1H NMR spectra of Mypyrl, Pyrl, Phpyrl and Tsyrl binding with LiPSs was shown in Fig. S10. It is observed that the resonance peaks of α-H of Pyrl and Mypyrl were shifted to lower field and to higher field for Tsyrl and Phpyrl when coupling with Li2S6. The chemical shift of α-H in Mypyrl, Pyrl, Phpyrl and Tsyrl and the changing trend of the chemical shift (Δδ) induced by binding of LiPSs was plotted in Fig. 3 , which is consistently related with the electron donating/withdrawing ability of the substitutional group [49,50]. Not only the interaction of pyrrole derivatives with LiPSs, but also the Co nanoparticles surface with pyrrole derivatives may also significantly affect the uptake of the molecular modifiers and the redox kinetics of LiPSs. The molecular interaction between pyrrole derivatives and Co nanoparticles surface was first explored by DFT calculation (Fig. 4 and Fig. S11). It is observed that the pyrrole and phenyl group in Tsyrl is almost perpendicular to each other and it can be adsorbed on Co surface either through pyrrole ring (Fig. 4a) or phenyl ring (Fig. S11). A shorter distance of Tsyrl to Co surface was observed when bonding through pyrrole group, which is 6.599 Å. It was shown that Phpyrl molecules adsorb on Co surface at a distance of 4.093 Å, where pyrrole and phenyl group form a flat surface and are fully conjugated with each other. This induces stronger coupling of Phpyrl with Co surface and shorter distance to Co surface than Pyrl and Mypyrl, while the variation of the surface distance is minimal among these three molecules. The interaction strength of pyrrole derivatives with Co surface may affect their loading on Co-CN composite. The loading of these pyrrole derivatives on Co-CN composite was further evaluated by soaking Co-CN composite in solution of 0.1 M pyrrole derivatives in ethanol for 12 h and the concentration of the residue of pyrrole derivatives in the supernatant was examined by 1H NMR, as shown in Figs. S12–S16. It was determined that the uptake of Tsyrl, Phpyrl, Pyrl and Mypyrl on Co-CN composite is 7.3, 46.5, 15.2 and 20.4 mmol g−1, respectively. Due to the highly conjugated planar molecular structure, the strongest interaction between Phpyrl and Co surface was observed, thus, displaying the highest uptake of Phpyrl on Co-CN composite (46.5 mmol g−1). In contrast, Tsyrl exhibits the longest distance to Co surface and the weakest interaction with Co surface, thus, the lowest uptake on Co-CN was observed (7.3 mmol g−1). This is in agreement with the polarization and rate performance on the pyrrole derivatives in Fig. 5 . However, although the uptake of Mypyrl on Co-CN composite is the second highest among them, it enables almost the largest polarization and lowest charge capacity for Li-S batteries. These results indicate that the interaction strength of pyrrole derivatives with both LiPSs and Co-CN are dominant factors in determining the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. It might be further concluded that weaker interaction of pyrrole derivatives with LiPSs (Fig. 3) and higher loading of pyrrole derivatives (Fig. 5) are beneficial to the electrochemical performances of Li-S batteries. The synergistic interaction among pyrrole derivatives, LiPSs and Co nanoparticles was further explored by DFT calculation in terms of analyzing the adsorption energy of LiPSs on bare and pyrrole derivatives-functionalized Co surface, respectively. By taking Phpyrl as an example, the adsorption configuration of Li2S6 on bare Co (111) and Phpyrl/Co (111) are shown in Fig. 6 (side view) and Fig. S17 (top view), respectively. It can be observed that when Li2S6 and Phpyrl adsorb on Co (111) in parallel, the adsorption strength of Li2S6 is significantly reduced, while it is enhanced when Li2S6 is between Phpyrl and Co (111). This indicates that the latter interaction mode (Fig. 6c) among LiPSs, Co and Pyrl might be effective in enhancing the redox kinetics of LiPSs. The chemical interaction between Co-CN and 1-phenylpyrrole was characterized by XPS [51]. Fig. S18(a) demonstrates the high-resolution XPS spectrum of N 1s, where the pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N are observed at 398.6, 399.7, and 401.1 eV for Co-CN, respectively [52–54]. It is observed that the intensity of pyrrolic N in Phpyrl/Co-CN is much stronger than that in Co-CN, ascribing to the loading of 1-phenylpyrrole on Co-CN. Fig. S18(b) displays the high-resolution XPS of Co 2p of Co-CN and Phpyrl/Co-CN. For Co-CN sample, the peaks of Co 2p were deconvoluted into two peaks at 778.3 and 793.9 eV for metallic Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, and two peaks at 780.2 and 797.2 eV ascribing to Co–N bond [55,56]. It should be noted that the peak intensity from metallic Co species in Co-CN sample is much higher than that of Co–N, indicating that metallic Co is dominating. In contrast, Co 2p band in Phpyrl/Co-CN sample attributed to Co–N bonding is much intensified upon surface functionalization of 1-phenylpyrrole, possibly due to the π interaction and also Co–N bonding between Co nanoparticles and 1-phenylpyrrole through pyrrolic nitrogen. The electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries with and without Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer was shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7(a) represents the long-term cycling performance of the Li-S battery with PP, Co-CN, and Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer under a current density of 0.2 C. The cell with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer presents an initial discharge capacity of 1354 mAh g−1 and keeps a capacity of 885 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles [57], which is much higher than that of the batteries using Co-CN interlayer (1157.1 and 762.5 mAh g−1) and pristine PP separator (916 and 586 mAh g−1). Besides, the initial discharge capacity of Li-S battery with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer under 0.05 C is 1421 mAh g−1, which is higher than that of Co-CN interlayer (1120 mAh g−1) and PP separator (1073 mAh g−1), as shown in Fig. 7(b) [58]. Notably, the cell with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer delivers the smallest polarization and the highest redox kinetics of LiPSs [59]. Especially, the discharge capacity of Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer is much higher than that of Co-CN interlayer and pristine PP separator at the low platform of 2.1 V, which indicates that Phpyrl/Co-CN can effectively promote the kinetics of short-chain LiPSs to Li2S. Similarly, this trend can also be found in the charge–discharge platforms for the batteries with PP, Co-CN, and Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer under the rate of 0.2 C after 200 cycles, which also confirms the superior electrochemical performance of the Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer (Fig. 7c). This can also be supported by the Tafel plots of the reduction of LiPSs. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the Tafel slope of Li-S batteries with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer is 83 mV dec–1, which is much smaller than that of Co–CN interlayer (115 mV dec–1) and PP separator (129 mV dec–1) [60], confirming the enhanced redox kinetics of LiPSs due to the Lewis interaction between 1-phenylpyrrole and LiPSs [61,62]. When the current density is 1 C, the battery with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer delivers an initial capacity of 836 mAh g−1 and still maintains a specific capacity of 538 mAh g−1 even after 500 cycles with a capacity decay of 0.071% per cycle and nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency (Fig. 7e). Likewise, it can be clearly seen that the long-term performance of the cell with a Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer is better than the batteries with PP and Co-CN interlayer. As shown in Fig. S19, the Q H and Q L and polarization voltage of Phpyrl/Co-CN in the 2nd and 500th cycle is superior to Co-CN and PP, which reveals that Phpyrl/Co-CN has a better catalytic ability for LiPSs and stable electrochemical process. To explore the effect of 1-phenylpyrrole monomers as interlayer of PP separator, we examined the cycling performance of Phpyrl/PP separator without using Co-CN composite at 1 and 2 C and also the rate performance. As shown in Fig. S20(a), Phpyrl/PP separator slightly enhances the capacity of the Li-S batteries, which remains 473 mAh g g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C, which is superior to that of pristine PP separator, but poorer than that using Phpyrl/Co-CN composite interlayer (538 mAh g−1). However, the entire performance is still quite poor as compared to that using Co-CN and the application of Co-CN is essential to achieve excellent electrochemical performance. When cycling at 0.2 C, it is shown in Fig. S20(b) that the Phpyrl/PP separator exhibits higher initial capacity but much faster decay rate than PP separator and the remaining capacity of the two batteries is quite similar to each other. This might indicate that 1-phenylpyrrole moieties deposited on the PP separator slowly dissolve into the electrolyte and lose the capability in suppressing the LiPSs. To confirm the stability of the interlayer against the cycling at such a current density, the cell was disassembled after cycling, characterized by SEM and elemental mapping and compared with the fresh sample, as shown in Fig. S21. It indicates that Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer can be well maintained after cycling and deposition of LiPSs was also observed. In addition, we further tested the redox kinetics of Phpyrl/Co-CN on LiPSs through a symmetric battery. As shown in Fig. S22, the charge transfer impedance on the Phpyrl/Co-CN electrode is significantly reduced, and the current density and enclosed area of the CV curve are higher than that of Co-CN, which suggests that Phpyrl promotes the redox kinetics of LiPSs [63–65]. Besides, even under the current density of 2 and 3 C, the battery can cycle to 500 cycles and still maintains a specific capacity of 526 and 449.9 mAh g−1 (Fig. 7f and g), respectively. To confirm that the lithium anode can be stable at such current density for 500 cycles, Li//Li symmetric cells were cycled at a current density of 5.0 mA cm−2 and capacity of 2.5 mAh cm−2 (Fig. S23). The standard electrolyte containing 10 mM Li2S6 was used to simulate the working condition of Li-S batteries. It was observed that the presence of Li2S6 apparently increases the polarization voltage of the Li//Li symmetric cell due to the reaction of Li2S6 with Li metal. However, the Li//Li symmetric cell using Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer can be stable more than 250 h when the electrolyte containing the with 10 mM Li2S6 and Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer enables a polarization of 34 mV after cycling of 250 h, which is superior to that of Co-CN, which exhibits a polarization of 93 mV. In order to explore the impact of the interlayer on the Li+ diffusion, the CV curves at different scanning speeds for Li-S batteries using various interlayers were acquired and the lithium-ion diffusion coefficients were calculated by using the Randles-Sevcik equation shown below [66]. I p = 2.69 × 10 5 n 1.5 A D 0.5 C v 0.5 where Ip represents the peak current, n is the number of electrons involved in the reaction, A is the area of the electrode, v is the scan rate, C is the Li+ concentration, D is the Li+ diffusion coefficient. As shown in Fig. S24, the Li+ diffusion coefficients at different peak positions are calculated by fitting the current density over the square root of the scanning rate, and the calculation results are summarized in Table S1. It is observed that Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer demonstrates the highest Li+ diffusion coefficient when fitting all the current density of the three peaks, which is beneficial for improving the performance of batteries [67]. The polarization of the Li-S batteries with varied interlayers at different scan rates can also be derived from the CV curves in Fig. S24. As shown in Fig. S25, the cell with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer owns the smallest polarization and highest current density at the three peaks, manifesting its superior redox kinetics compared to the other two batteries. The performance of Li-S batteries with high sulfur loading (>2 mg cm−2) was carried out. The long-term cycling performance of the cells with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer with a sulfur loading of 2.5 and 3.5 mg cm−2 is shown in Fig. 8 (a), respectively. It delivers the initial discharge capacity of 1197 and 1108 mAh g−1 with a sulfur loading of 2.5 and 3.5 mg cm−2, and maintains a specific capacity of 701 and 599 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles respectively (Fig. 8b) [68]. The galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles exhibit two obvious platforms, which prove the stability of the battery under high sulfur loading. As shown in Fig. 8(c), even under the current density of 0.2 C, the battery with sulfur loading of 2.5 and 3.5 mg cm–2 can cycle up to 100 cycles, and maintains a capacity of 760.3 and 758.5 mAh g−1, respectively. When a sulfur loading is raised to 5.5 mg cm−2, the Li-S batteries with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer still deliver a high initial discharge capacity of 1212 mAh g−1 and maintain 450 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 8d). Besides, even under low E/S = 5 mL g−1, the battery with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer can still cycle up to 100 cycles with a capacity of 525.8 mAh g−1 under a current density of 0.1 C (Fig. S26), indicating its excellent electrochemical performance under lean electrolyte condition. As summarized in Table S2, the cell with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer offers better performance than other modified separators. The adsorption experiments were carried out to further understand the interaction of 1-phenylpyrrole with LiPSs [69]. As shown in Fig. S27, the adsorption experiment and the UV test after adsorption show that Phpyrl/Co-CN displays higher adsorption capacity of PSs, which can effectively inhibit the shuttle of LiPSs during discharging. 4 Conclusions In summary, we reported the surface functionalization of porous carbon supported-cobalt nanoparticles (Co-CN) by four pyrrole derivatives (1-phenylpyrrole, 1-methyl pyrrole, 1-(p-toluenesulfonyl) pyrrole, and 1-pyrrole), respectively, which were screened in terms of the electron donating/withdrawing ability. The composite was used as an interlayer of separator for Li-S batteries and the impact of the molecular structure of pyrrole derivatives on the redox dynamics of LiPSs and electrochemical performance was explored. The interaction of pyrrole derivatives with LiPSs and Co surface was explored by 1H NMR and DFT calculation. It was found that both of them are playing roles in regulating the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Among these pyrrole derivatives, 1-phenylpyrrole exhibits the weakest interaction with LiPSs, strongest coupling with Co and highest uptake on Co-CN composite. In contrast, 1-(p-toluenesulfonyl) pyrrole, although showing quite weak interaction with LiPSs, demonstrates the weakest coupling with Co surface and also lowest loading, enabling the poorest electrochemical performance. It is also believed that the pyrrole moieties adsorb on Co surface through π bonds and LiPSs interact with both Co surface and pyrrole, which introduces surface confinement effect and synergistically promotes the catalytic conversion of LiPSs. Thus, the Li-S batteries with Phpyrl/Co-CN interlayer exhibit a highest excellent rate performance (562 mAh g−1 at 5 C) and a superior cycling capacity (538 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C with a capacity decay of 0.071% per cycle). Moreover, it can also cycle for up to 500 cycles at 1 C under a high sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2 with a capacity of 440 mAh g−1. This work unravels the synergistic coupling mechanism among LiPSs, pyrrole derivatives and Co nanoparticles improving the redox kinetics of LiPSs, which may shed light design of high performance and functional interlayers for Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: The electrochemical performance of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries is strongly hampered by the shuttle effect and slow redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). Surface modified interlayer of a separator of Li-S batteries is demonstrated to be an effective strategy to overcome this problem. Herein, cobalt nanoparticles confined in nitrogen co-doped porous carbon framework (Co-CN) were developed from pyrolysis of ZIF-67 and used as interlayer of PP separator for Li-S batteries, and were functionalized by four pyrrole derivatives, 1-phenylpyrrole, 1-methyl pyrrole, 1-(p-toluenesulfonyl) pyrrole, and 1-pyrrole, respectively, which were screened in terms of the electron-withdrawing/donating ability of the substituent groups on the pyrrolic nitrogen. The impact of the molecular structure of pyrrole derivatives on the interaction with LiPSs and the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries were explored by nuclear magnetic resonance and theoretical calculation. It is uncovered that 1-phenylpyrrole shows the highest enhancement of redox kinetics of LiPSs, attributing to the optimal interaction with Co nanoparticles and LiPSs. Therefore, 1-phenylpyrrole modified Co-CN interlayer enables the best electrochemical performance for the Li-S batteries, delivering a specific capacity of 562 mAh g−1 at 5 C and a capacity of 538, 526, and 449 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1, 2, and 3 C, respectively. At a high sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2, it achieves a capacity of 440 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C. This work reveals the interaction mechanism among LiPSs, Co nanoparticles and the molecular modifiers in improving the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Pyrrole derivatives as interlayer modifier of Li-S batteries: Modulation of electrochemical performance by molecular perturbation
